results.title: Possums of Bonegilla
results.creator_credit: ACMI Digital Storytelling and Agnes Karlik
results.brief_description: Agnes talks of her migrant experience including her time spent at Bonegilla. She especially focuses on friendships made during those early years of alienation and loneliness.

results.title: Possum's tale
results.brief_description:
“My country is in my heart everywhere I go. My country is in my blood no matter what happens to me. My country is my family and my community…”
This is a poetic documentary exploring the spiritual connection between Aboriginal people and the country they were born in. It recreates the childhood experience of the director, Josie Atkinson, as she attempts to return home to her country as a young child.

results.title: Possibly so, Pythagoras (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Katharine Cornwell, Bruce Cornwell and Prairie Du Sao
results.brief_description: Investigates the Pythagorean theorem through inductive experimentation as well as through formal deductive proof. Gives an insight into the meaning of mathematical discovery by observation and experiment, and can be shown when geometry is first formally introduced as well as during the study of the famous theorem.

results.title: Possessed
results.brief_description: Marion, a factory worker from Pennsylvania, has a glimpse of the high life and goes to New York to find such a life for herself. Marian is a quick learner and it is not long before she becomes mistress of a rich prominent lawyer, Mark Whitney. “Possessed” is a fascinating, trenchant drama with a strong screenplay based on the play “The mirage” by Edgar Selwyn. Stars Joan Crawford and Clark Cable.

results.title: Positioning for Function Workshop
results.brief_description: Seating and positioning for handicapped clients is thoroughly examined in this video and careful attention is given to designing equipment which meets, as fully as is possible, the individual needs. Such attention to design assists in maximising function.

results.title: Ports of industrial Scandinava
results.brief_description: A journey down the east coast of Sweden by tramp steamer through the Gulf of Bothnia to the Baltic Sea with stops at various ports to unload cargo. It is winter and because the Gulf is not very salty is freezes easily. Lumber products are an important export. The trees are cut chiefly in winter by men who are frequently farmers in summer. Logs are bought to the pulp mills and the process of making wood pulp is shown. Steel and iron products are important exports from a region where iron mines and water power are abundant. Stockholm is the last stop and the home port, and we are shown something of the city, including the home surroundings of the first mate of the ship who goes ashore for a visit to his family.

results.title: Portraits: people with epilepsy
results.creator_credit: Samantha Shepherd, Donna Graham and Epilepsy Queensland
results.brief_description: Five people from different walks of life talk about their experience with epilepsy. Hugo Weaving tells of how it affects/doesn’t affect his work as an actor. Retiree Jean reflects on her life as an epileptic mother. Chef Ian addresses how he adapts his work in a stressful job to accommodate his condition. Uni student Sally talks about what it was like to study, then travel overseas, and primary school teacher Amanda explains how her students cope in the classroom. The five talk candidly about their achievements and how epilepsy has affected their lives. Funded by the Health Advancement Branch of Queensland Health and produced for Epilepsy Queensland.

results.title: Portrait of Zubin Mehta
results.creator_credit: Terry Sanders Productions, Erik Daarstad and Terry Sanders
results.brief_description: The story of Zubin Mehta, a young Indian-born conductor of the Los Angeles Symphony Orchestra and the Metropolitan Opera House Company. Follows the conductor on his daily routine - rehearsals, meetings, performances, and back-stage life - and on his world tour with the orchestra, winding up at his birth place in Bombay. Ends with Ravel’s arrangement of Mussorgsky’s “Pictures at an exhibition”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Terry Sanders Productions, Erik Daarstad and Terry Sanders

results.title: Portrait of the artist as an old lady
results.creator_credit: Gail Singer and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Paraskeva Clark, artist, socialist, feminist, is her own woman at her own cost. This film is a cameo of an irascible and oftentimes touching artist whose work has won her a place in exhibitions and private collections. Born in Russia in 1898, she eventually married a Canadian and moved to Toronto. Because her canvases reflect a strong social conscience, she had to struggle hard to earn a place in the nation’s ultra-conservative galleries. With Germaine Greer narrating, this film explores Clarke’s early life through photographs, reminiscences and her painting. (Awards: Montrial, Melbourne)
